comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Evolution of a hole in the ground...It's good to have a precise date for this pic...also see this earlier pic www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/8662355990/

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: "Site for New Public Buildings" - Does anyone know what was built there after 1899 until the 1980s Museum of Sydney?

comment.author: 73199923@N00
comment._content: "...For almost 140 years after the demolition of First Government House in 1845, the Site remained Government property and went through many uses; as a carter's yard, a temporary office for the Public Works Department, and a car park. But, by an amazing stroke of fortune, no building of any permanence was erected upon it, and the 1788 foundations lay buried, largely undisturbed, in a remarkable state of preservation..." www.ffghs.org.au/page7.php

comment.author: 35179849@N08
comment._content: I am having trouble seeing how this could be Bridge and Phillip,   because neither of those roads is crooked.   Could it be Phillip and Bent street,   and you are looking at the back of the site on Phillip and Bridge ?

comment.author: 97539983@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/mich2009] Mich, it's definitely Bridge St. heading of to the right. The building with the dome is still there (opposite Macquarie Place park), I don't think Phillip St. is "crooked", but it gets wider and the tram lines were re-aligned. The Metropole Hotel had frontages on Young, Bent and Phillip streets, so it all fits.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: State Records NSW The tram tracks are leading into what was known as the 'Bridge Street Yard' - the northern most terminus for the steam trams on the Elizabeth Street run. Lack of overhead would indicate that the shot was taken before electrification (21/12/1902). To see a picture of the Bridge Street yard follow this link [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper/5376634691]

comment.author: 97539983@N07
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper]  Can also be seen on this 1927 map of Sydney. View at original resolution. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/6662642331/in/set-72157606230401212/]

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/97539983@N07] Here's a shot from my photostream showing a steam motor entering the Bridge Street Yard [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper/5487521403]
